name: 2ping
desc: a 2-way ping, able to find out if a packet was lost on the way to a 2ping server or on the way back

name: 389-ds
desc: named "Fedora Directory Server" before they got cold feet about the branding - see the FAQ. If you don't see the answer to the question there, it's because they're assuming you know that LDAP uses port 389

name: abcde
desc: a better CD encoder (in the sense of "it's a CD encoder that's better than its rivals", not "it makes a better CD encoder than a window manager")

name: abiword
desc: the word processor designed for AbiSource's AbiSuite, where "abi(erto)" is Spanish for "open"

name: acme
desc: the ACME Crossassembler for Multiple Environments

name: adequate
desc: installed package adequacy checker; or rather, a Debian quality tester

name: aewm
desc: an exiguous (that is, meager or scanty) window manager

name: aft
desc: a markup tool which is almost free text

name: agave
desc: (ex-package) a palette-coordinating tool, previously known as colorscheme; but that gave the wrong impression of its functionality, hence the switch to something completely uninformative - the agave isn't exactly renowned for its beauty, though I suppose the "G" might hint at a GNOME connection

name: agedu
desc: it's "age-du" (as in, atime-sensitive disk-usage scanner), not "agadoo", but the confusion is officially tolerated

name: aisleriot
desc: solitaire; an anagram

name: akonadi-*
desc: KDE PIM service; the name (with a "K" in it) of a Ghanaian goddess (of justice and protection)

name: alacarte
desc: previously the Simple Menu Editor for Gnome. Some may see why that was renamed; the new version is intended to convey the idea of picking things off the menu

name: aladin
desc: (interactive sky atlas) because it uses the SIMBAD database (a Set of Identifications, Measurements and Bibliography for Astronomical Data). Spelled  French-style with one D

name: algol68g
desc: "Algol 68 Genie", a compiler/interpreter for the 1968 standard (revised in 1973) for the Algorithmic Language (punning on the "demon star" Algol)

name: alpine
desc: Apache-Licensed PINE, where pine was the old (non-DFSG-free) "Program for Internet News and E-mail" - formerly known though they say this was already a backronym as "Pine Is Nearly Elm", named after a yet older electronic mail program. Nowadays contains its fork realpine, which the developers insist is re-alpine (alpine development restarted, since the original team seems to not be doing much) and not real-pine…

name: amarok
desc: (ex-package) a music player for KDE named after a Mike Oldfield album which is named in turn after an Inuit word for "wolf" - so definitely a "cool animal" (though technically isn't the Inuit word "Amaroq", without the all-important "K"?)

name: amavisd-new
desc: now the only surviving version of "a mail virus scanner daemon" (how does such an uninspired name survive multiple generations of rewrites?)

name: ampache
desc: (ex-package) (web media-server) amplifier + Apache (q.v.); you might imagine that has some connection with Winamp, but that AMP originally stood for Advanced Media Products (the MP3 player Winamp was built around)

name: anjuta
desc: GNOME IDE named after its designer's girlfriend

name: anki
desc: (flashcard system) Japanese for "memorize, learn by rote"

name: anope
desc: most IRC services daemons have classical names, and this looks like another one - it even looks vaguely as if it should be Ancient Greek for "faceless" - but in fact it's just the word "epona" backwards, since anope is based on another IRC daemon of that name (Epona being a Gaulish mare-goddess)

name: anorack
desc: an indefinite-article validator, i.e. "an-or-a-checker"; it's sheer coincidence that this synonym for "parka" also happens to be British slang for "nerd/trainspotter/obsessive nitpicker"

name: ansible
desc: (software configuration management framework) nothing to do with ANSI - instead it's named after a science-fictional instantaneous communications device.  (The developer who named the software originally attributed the term to the author Orson Scott Card, but Card was borrowing it from Ursula K Le Guin.)

name: ant
desc: Apache's Java build tool; an appropriate animal justified as "another neat tool"

name: anthy
desc: (Japanese character-convertor), named after Anthy Himemiya, a character from the anime "Revolutionary Girl Utena" but not the kind of character that regularly converts

name: aodh-*
desc: (OpenStack alarm service, forked out of ceilometer) an Irish name pronounced just like the letter "A" and meaning "fire" - see also heat

name: apache
desc: legendarily a pun on “A Patchy Server”, since it started as a collection of patches to the NCSA httpd; but the current official version is that it's named after the Apache tribe of Native Americans, who were skilled in warfare. One of the creators of Apache, Brian Behlendorf, came up with the name out of the blue – he liked the connotations of aggressiveness.  Mind you, BB was one of the ones who spent the nineties handing out the "patchy" version...

name: apt
desc: "APT" was originally announced as simply "a package tool"; these days people seem to prefer either advanced package tool or (the slightly less apt alternative) advanced packaging tool, but none of these answers are officially official

name: arandr
desc: another XRandR client, because there were already clients called XRandR, GRandR, URandR, and LXRandR by the time it was created. XRandR itself stands for "X resize and rotate"

name: ardour
desc: ("digital audio workstation") so called for a whole collection of reasons

name: argonaut-*
desc: (server-client distributed deployment infrastructure) for some of the package descriptions in the suite this name is a groan-inducingly obvious Greek-mythology pun, but others don't even mention that its message protocol is encoded in JavaScript Object Notation

name: argyll
desc: (color calibration manager) apparently named after the street the developer lived on, which is in turn (maybe fortuitously) named after a region of Scotland associated with tartans (which are basically standardized colorschemes - not to be confused with the Argyle pattern mostly seen on garishly colored golf outfits)

name: aseba
desc: (classroom robot control system) apparently a reference to the Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment used in child psychology

name: asmix
desc: a dockable mixer (that is, a volume control knob) originally designed for the afterstep window-manager (compare gnustep), as were a good few other nineties packages with names beginning with "A" or especially "AS"; many of them were later replaced by "WM" versions for windowmaker

name: asp
desc: (dynamic-IP-address discovery tool) address search protocol

name: aspell
desc: (spell checker) designed to replace ispell, in particular in -a (auto?) mode or maybe it's a spell checker with an advanced adaptive advisory approximation algorithm, unless it was just an apparently arbitrary available alphanumeric

name: asterisk
desc: (PBX) "The name 'Asterisk' was chosen because it was both a key on a standard telephone and also the wildcard symbol"

name: atomicparsley
desc: (MPEG-4 metadata editor) "atoms" are the building blocks of MPEG-4 container units, and "parsley" is a reference to garnishing files with extra information and/or a pun on "parser"

name: atril
desc: (evince fork for MATE, thematically named in Spanish) "lectern" - i.e. a thing for reading from

name: auctex
desc: a TeX-editing environment for Emacs developed at what was then the Aalborg University Center, Denmark

name: audacious
desc: player punning on "audio", not to be confused with audacity. BMP (Beep Media Player, originally just called Beep) was a fork of XMMS (see xmms2), and Audacious in turn is a fork of BMP; somewhere along the way it stopped being a WinAmp clone

name: audacity
desc: audio editor with a punning name - compare timidity

name: augeas-tools
desc: (CLI configuration-file management utilities) in Greek myth, King Augeas was the one who didn't clean out the legendarily filthy Augean Stables - indeed, he even tried to cheat Hercules out of the reward for successfully doing so. You can guess how well that ended

name: autopoint
desc: a build tool for a source package's GNU gettext localization infrastructure; that is, it automates setting up the required po/, intl/, and m4/ directories (cf. po-debconf)

name: avahi-*
desc: (zeroconf implementation) the obscure animal name struck a developer as cool

name: awk
desc: (virtual package) see mawk

name: ayatana-*
desc: a piece of Buddhist philosophical jargon usually translated "sense base" something we ought to be trying not to get hung up on, which makes it an odd name for a project to develop a pretty UI

name: ayttm
desc: (ex-package) (IM client) originally YATTM (Yet Another Typical Text Messager? You All Talk Too Much?) but misspelled when the project-name was registered; since backronymed as "are you talking to me?"

name: azureus
desc: (ex-package) (BitTorrent client) named after the genus of "azure-colored" poison-dart frog in its logo (Upstream have rebranded as "Vuze", but that's a GPL app with a clickthrough EULA...)

name: bacula
desc: I suppose you could argue that it comes out at night and sucks your company's lifeblood over the network, but it really is just an excruciating pun on backups and Dracula (slightly excused by the spin-off acronym of the Bacula Admin Tool)

name: baloo*
desc: (KDE metadata search framework replacing libnepomuk) given that this is the successor to basenji and before that beagle, both named after breeds of hunting dog, maybe it's because "Baloo" is popular as a name for individual hounds? But whether directly or indirectly, it comes from the name of the bear in "Jungle Book", which Kipling took from the Hindi word for "bear", bhaalu

name: balsa
desc: a GNOME mailclient, named in the tradition of pine and elm (see alpine)

name: bangarang
desc: (ex-package) (KDE media player) Jamaican slang for hubbub, uproar

name: banshee
desc: (ex-package) (GNOME media management application) originally "Sonance", but renamed after a supernatural entity that produces ill-omened keening (because apparently that's what people want out of their PCs these days... wait, a music app based on Mono and it didn't get called Stereo?)

name: barrier
desc: (free fork of Synergy) a mechanism to let machines share mouse/keyboard, named backwards for the thing it eliminates

name: baobab
desc: (the GNOME Disk Usage Analyzer) a bloaty tree

name: barbican-*
desc: (OpenStack key management service) named after the gatehouse in the outer wall of a castle

name: bc
desc: originally a front-end for dc ("desk-calculator"); modern GNU bc is instead a backwards-compatible byte-code interpreter for dc, but what it stands for is still "basic calculator"

name: biff
desc: traditional UNIX mail notification tool named after somebody's dog

name: bind9
desc: yes, it stands for "Berkeley Internet name domain (version nine)", but what's a "name domain" (as opposed to a domain name)? The original unabbreviated name was "the Berkeley Internet Name Domain Server" - that is, it was the UCB domain-server for Internet-names.

name: bins
desc: (ex-package) (photo album generator) anyone remember SWIGS, Structured Web Image Gallery System? BINS is not SWIGS

name: biomaj
desc: (ex-package) a biological database updater; for francophones it's obvious that mise-à-jour means "update"

name: bison
desc: a pun on yacc

name: bitlbee
desc: (IRC/IM gateway) Anglo-Dutch gibberish

name: black
desc: a Python code formatter that works on the Ford principle "Any color you like as long as it's black"

name: blender
desc: (3D animator) not directly named after the kitchen appliance; it was a song (by Yello) used as backing music for a demo of an earlier incarnation

name: bluefish
desc: (HTML editor) named after its logo (not the same blue fish as its current logo)

name: bluez
desc: (tools for using shortrange Bluetooth wireless devices) upstream write it as BlueZ, implying it's "bloo-zee" rather than just "blooz"; the significance of the Z is unclear, but the rest is easy. The protocol is named after the 10th-century Danish king Harald "Blåtand" Gormsson, who was (supposedly) skilled at fostering cooperation between diverse factions, and (maybe) overfond of blueberries (Then again there are also rumours that early prototype receivers were blue and tooth-shaped)

name: bochs
desc: (classic x86 PC emulator) claims to be a play on the word "box", but unless there's a pun I'm not seeing it's just a whimsical misspelling

name: bonnie++
desc: this package's description passes the buck to bonnie, which (when last seen, in Potato) had the description "a file system benchmark which attempts to study bottlenecks - it is named 'Bonnie' for semi-obvious reasons." Don't get it? The reason is that blues/country musician Bonnie Raitt plays slide guitar using a bottleneck.

name: borgbackup
desc: a backup framework forked from Jonas Borgström's attic by a group of developers going by the name "the Borg Collective" whatever the reason for this name I'm sure it can't have been any sort of reference to Paramount's intellectual property

name: brasero
desc: (CD-burner) from the Spanish for "heater" - i.e. a burner

name: bro
desc: (network sniffer) decades ago this was short for an Orwellian Big Brother; since then the word has picked up unwelcome connotations, so upstream has switched to zeek, a Gary Larson reference

name: brotli
desc: a compression tool named after a Swiss bakery product (cf.zopfli); in this case Brötli (or Brödli) = "little bread, bun"

name: brz
desc: brz=breezy is a fork of bzr=bazaar

name: bsd*
desc: a few packages have names beginning with BSD not to indicate that they are specific to the Debian GNU/kFreeBSD ports but to signal that Linux distros originally inherited them from (the earliest clearly free versions of) the Berkeley Software Distribution

name: bsd-mailx
desc: an example of the above; this is a BSD-derived replacement for the original UNIX mail command. The names of different versions have a tangled history (and even that link doesn't directly explain the "X"; presumably it's for "extended")

name: bsdowl
desc: a BSD make tool "dedicated to Pallas Athene" in reference to the Max-Planck Gesellschaft (but nothing to do with Project Athena) Also, French users would pronounce it bestiole which could be translated back to beastie, which is the nickname of the BSD daemon.

name: btrfs-progs
desc: (formerly btrfs-tools) BTRFS is the B-tree File System, but if that abbreviation didn't suggest "BetterFS" there would be no reason to include the "R" (ReiserFS meanwhile is probably better off not mentioning Hans Reiser)

name: buffy
desc: (new-mail summarizer - see also xbuffy, etc.) a spin-off from biff, because before she got her own TV show Buffy was the girlfriend of the mythical eighties newbie USENET poster BIFF@BIT.NET.

name: bugzilla*
desc: originally the bugtracking tool used by Netscape for Mozilla, Chatzilla, etc, so the -zilla part isn't intended to carry its usual negative connotations ("huge, monstrous, and uncontrollably destructive")

name: bumblebee
desc: software to support NVIDIA Optimus hardware, thematically named after a "Transformers" character

name: burrow
desc: a performance monitor for Kafka named after an unfinished short story

name: butteraugli
desc: another image-compression tool from Google with a name from Swiss pastry-making (literally "(little-)butter-eye")

name: byobu
desc: a command line "window manager" built on  tmux/GNU Screen, named from the Japanese word (byōbu) for a screen (in the folding-panel room-divider sense)

name: caca-utils
desc: libcaca pretends to be an acronym for "Color AsCii Art", but really it's self-deprecating code: "caca" means "poo" in French.  As the website explains (via a quote in French), "everything useful is ugly"

name: cairo*
desc: the Cairo graphics library was originally named Xr ("X11 rendering"?), then renamed as something less platform-specific: "Cairo" sounds like chi-rho, which is vaguely equivalent to Xr

name: caja
desc: (nautilus fork for MATE, thematically named in Spanish) "case/chest/countertop" (pronounced to rhyme with "baja")

name: calibre
desc: (manager for e-book catalogs, or maybe with that un-American spelling it should be catalogues) that's "libre" as in liberté, not (just) libr- as in library

name: calligra
desc: (formerly known as KOffice) just a brandname suggesting "calligraphy" and mysteriously lacking a "K"

name: canto
desc: (ex-package) (text Atom/RSS feedreader) looks like a Console Atom News-something, but apparently it's just because it has a subdivided UI and a canto is a subdivision of a poem

name: caspar
desc: (make-based CMS) the man page used to explain that it was "named after Caspar the Friendly Ghost, since that's the title of the Daniel Johnston song I was listening to"

name: cclive
desc: successor for clive written in C. clive must have been a command-line-interface video-extractor (because it certainly wasn't a Virtual Environment written in the .NET Common Language Infrastructure)

name: ceilometer-*
desc: (OpenStack metering service) named after an instrument for measuring cloud coverage

name: ceph
desc: (OpenStack storage) short for "cephalopod", though not for any reason you'd be likely to guess; supposedly it's a reference to parallelization and/or a university's mollusc mascot

name: chafa
desc: another self-deprecating name for a (non-ASCII) "ASCII art" package; New-World Spanish for "shoddy"

name: charliecloud
desc: the boss was named Charles

name: chicken-*
desc: a scheme compiler; the name was inspired by a toy chicken  (or actually an evil penguin disguised as a chicken)

name: chimera2
desc: (ex-package) a remarkable number of web browsers have used this name, including the OS X one that was better known as Camino; this one's much older (and yet still only claims to be an alpha release). Its use of the Athena widget set explains the classical connection; otherwise like most of its namesakes it's probably advertising itself as a monstrous hybrid

name: chocolate-doom
desc: (contrib) a pun on "Vanilla Doom", a common term used within the Doom gaming community to refer to the original doom.exe on MS-DOS. Chocolate Doom aims to emulate it as closely as possible

name: choqok
desc: a KDE (hence often written "choqoK") microblogging client "named from an ancient Persian word for sparrow" (that's چغوک, pronounced [tʃʊˈqʊk], apparently Khorasan dialect; but Old Persian had no /q/, so where did that come from?)

name: chromium
desc: web browsers on Linux spent a decade going through a cycle of slick new slimline web browsers gradually getting buried in creeping features until they were as weighed down with chrome grills and ornamental fins as a fifties US car, at which point everyone would switch to some new minimalist alternative. Meanwhile these GUI widgets came to be referred to as "chrome", which explains why Google would choose to advertise their browser as if it was manufactured entirely out of deadweight bling...

name: chuck
desc: ("Audio Programming Language") built around a dataflow "chuck" operator - the language name is written "ChucK", but that just seems to be because related software had similar capitalization

name: cinder-*
desc: (OpenStack block-storage service) as in "cinderblock" if only they'd gone for en_GB it could have been "breeze(block)"!

name: cinnamon
desc: Linux Mint's fork of gnome-shell; seemingly a thematic flavorsome name - cf. mate were they perhaps particularly thinking of things like Cinnamon Altoids?

name: clevis
desc: encryption framework named after a type of shackle fastener

name: clisp
desc: Common Lisp, originally a list-processing language

name: clojure
desc: (JVM Lisp variant) the word includes the letters C (for C/C#), L (Lisp), and J (Java), puns on "closure", and was a free domainname

name: conkeror
desc: (ex-package) (web browser) a pun on konqueror and a reference to a novelty beer, but basically a word for the winner in the traditional British children's game of conkers

name: conky-*
desc: (contrib) system monitor; named after an evil dummy character in the Canadian mockumentary TV series "Trailer Park Boys"

name: coreutils
desc: the package itself has a clear name, but its contents include many commands named in shorthand: dd: on IBM system/360 mainframes, the Job Control Language used a dd-like syntax to create a Dataset Definition.  Legend has it that "Copy and Convert" would have been cc, but that was already the C compiler; dd was the next-best thing (alphabetically). Some users prefer "data/disk destroyer" or "delete data", which, thanks to its non-unix-y interface, is what the user may end up actually doing when trying to duplicate data or disks. mknod: originally created any sort of "file system node"; nowadays of extremely limited usefulness. ptx: an inscrutable abbreviation for a word-salad generator. PermuTed indeXes were tortuous concordances for manual pages back in the days before tools like apropos. The GNU version was created in 1999 as some sort of exercise in medieval reenactment. uname: short for "UNIX name", which makes it bizarre that the version now standard comes from a project that's explicitly Not UNIX...

name: corosync
desc: (cluster interprocess messaging framework) I'm really hoping this is coro as in the Portuguese/Spanish/Italian for "chorus" (or conceivably "coroutine"), plus sync as in "(virtual) synchrony", and has nothing to do with coronary syncopation a.k.a. cardiac arrhythmia

name: cortina
desc: (GNOME wallpaper app) Italian for "curtain" (and an old rustbucket brand of car which is a UK cultural icon)

name: cowpatty
desc: (wifi brute-forcer) a word that contains -WPA-

name: cpio
desc: the archiving tool does indeed "copy in/out", but this package also includes an executable that's harder to guess the function of: "mt-gnu", the GNU version of the magnetic tape manipulation tool

name: cricket
desc: "I called it Cricket because it popped into mind. It's short and catchy, and there seems to be no other piece of network management software called Cricket". The logo clarifies that it's referencing the chirpy insect, not the game

name: crm114
desc: a reference to Dr Strangelove (where an oversensitive CRM114 Discriminator causes the nuclear apocalypse) partly justified by the backronym "controllable regex mutilator"

name: curl
desc: the FAQ says it's "a play on 'Client for URLs', originally with URL spelled in uppercase to make it obvious it deals with URLs. The fact it can also be pronounced 'see URL' also helped, it works as an abbreviation for 'Client URL Request Library' or why not the recursive version: 'Curl URL Request Library'"

name: cw
desc: a front-end to the Morse processor unixcw. "CW" originally stood for "continuous wave radio", but hams use it as (written) shorthand for "Morse" regardless of the medium

name: cwm
desc: (window manager inspired by evilwm) also known as calmwm

name: cyrus-*
desc: mail server; named in honor of King Cyrus II ("the Great") of Persia, who established an early postal network (why has this page ended up with so many Persian references?)

name: dansguardian
desc: Daniel Barron's web-censoring server, which "guards" web users from the things it's filtering

name: daphne
desc: (server for Django Channels) named after a Django Reinhardt composition

name: darcs
desc: the package description seems to imply it stands for Distributed Interactive Revision Control System, which of course it doesn't; the D was originally for "David (Roundy)'s", but he preferred the recursive Darcs Advanced RCS

name: dares
desc: recovery tool for damaged optical discs; for some reason only the German docs admit it's short for data-rescue

name: dbus
desc: yes, it's a "message bus", but what's that when it's at home? The answer is that it's a data transport system - a standard software engineering technical term coined by analogy with hardware "buses" such as PCI, which are themselves named after electrical-engineering "busbars", which got their name in the days when the omnibus was the latest in transport technology. Third-generation jargon! Meanwhile, although it's nowhere to be seen in the official docs, Wikipedia claims the "D" stands for Desktop.  See also the input-method framework ibus, where the connection to the original vehicular metaphor is even more tenuous

name: dconf-*
desc: a replacement for GConf (the GNOME Configurator), where the "D" may stand for D-Bus or directly for "Desktop"; not connected to the ex-package "dconf" where it was D for Dump, or maybe Distributed

name: denemo
desc: GUI for lilypond, the music typesetting system. denemo is a garbled version of the word "dénouement" (compare the commercial alternative "Finale"). The name lilypond itself references the slightly earlier rosegarden and a friend named Suzanne (etymologically "lily")

name: designate
desc: (OpenStack DNS-as-a-Service) a synonym for (the verb) "name"

name: desmume
desc: (Nintendo DS emulator) an odd garbling of "DS-emu-Me", in the style of "hacking" tools like FlashMe  (meanwhile, "DS" was originally "Developer System")

name: dillo
desc: an earlier web browser was named "gzilla" (a GTK mini-Mozilla), then since that was just too close, "armadillo"; this fork is a cut-down version

name: ding
desc: allegedly dictionary nice grep, but note that "Ding" is the German for "thing/thingummy"

name: diodon
desc: (GNOME clipboard manager) another arbitrary(?) animal: Diodon is a genus of blowfish (named from Greek "two-tooth")

name: dirvish
desc: (backup system) because it writes to spinning media - like external SSDs instead of tape spools... uh, hang on a minute.  And aren't whirling dervishes spelled with an E?  So maybe the acronym theory makes more sense after all

name: *django
desc: (Python web-app development framework) named after jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt, the famous  Belgian (whose (nick)name means "I awake" in Romani)

name: dolphin
desc: (KDE file manager) a not-quite-arbitrary cool animal, in that it's smart and streamlined (and compare GNOME's equivalent, nautilus)

name: doxygen
desc: got its name from playing with the words "documentation" and "generator" (documentation → docs → dox, and generator → gen). At the time the author was looking into lex and yacc, where a lot of things start with "yy", so the "Y" slipped in and made things pronounceable (Makes me think of Doxies in Harry Potter, which are a nameplay on toxic; even more so as automatically generated "documentation" is often toxic to real documentation. -- Except that doxygen was named before doxies appeared in the HP videogames, and centuries after the word doxy appeared in English!)

name: dracut
desc: (low-level tool for generating initramfs images) a small town in Massachusetts, not all that far from Plymouth

name: drupal*
desc: (ex-package) PHP blog engine; mangled Dutch for "droplet", named after the (former) online community at drop.org, which in turn was originally a typo for "dorp", village (so it's double Dutch)

name: dune
desc: (OCaml builder) camel-themed SF reference

name: dunst
desc: dmenu-ish universal notification system (and German for "haze", or maybe even a reference to the actress Kirsten Dunst); dmenu is the Dynamic menu app included in suckless-tools

name: dynamite
desc: it "blows up" (meaning "inflates", meaning decompresses) PKWARE (i.e. .zip) archives (was the word "unzip" patented or something?)

name: eclipse
desc: (Java IDE) the Eclipse Foundation may be essentially a project to support Java development in a Sunless environment, but when it was named the thing it was intended to eclipse was MS Visual Studio - the snub to Sun Microsystems is an accident! (Sun itself being named after the Stanford University Network)

name: eiciel
desc: (GNOME ACL-editor) a spelling in phonetic Spanish of the English initialism for "Access Control Lists" Technically when you edit those lists you're changing actual individual Access Control Entities, but oddly nobody ever talks about ACEs

name: ekiga
desc: (ex-package) VoIP client formerly known as GnomeMeeting; from a Cameroonian communications mechanism rather like "talking drums" minus the drums

name: elk
desc: the extension language kit - an implementation of Scheme (cf. guile), and yet another free software ungulate

name: elpa-*
desc: software from the Emacs Lisp package archive

name: emacs*
desc: originally a set of Editor MACroS for the TECO editor; see also xemacs

name: emesene
desc: (ex-package) obviously something to do with the MSN protocol; less obviously just the initialism spelled out in Spanish

name: enchant
desc: a wrapper for spellchecking systems named as a pun on "spelling"

name: engrampa
desc: (file-roller fork for MATE, thematically named in Spanish) staple/bind/clip together

name: epic5
desc: enhanced programmable IRC-II client (version five)

name: epiphany-*
desc: GNOME web browser; the word means "a moment of insight or (mystical) revelation", so maybe it's just a fancy way of saying "it's an idea I had" (but meanwhile it's being renamed web, which is obvious to the point of namehoggery)

name: eric
desc: an IDE for Python overtly named after Monty Python's Eric Idle (compare idle)

name: erlang
desc: a programming language either named after a Danish mathematician/engineer or after the fact it's a language originally developed by Ericsson (for telephony)

name: etherape
desc: a packetsniffer punningly named after the Windows-only EtherMan, where "Man" was short for man-in-the-middle. Not connected to "the Ether Man", the media nickname for a serial rapist

name: ettercap
desc: an ethernet capture tool; it's also a lurking horror capable of ARP poisoning, so it's named after a venomous AD&D spider-monster

name: evince
desc: (document viewer) swanky word for "show"

name: evolution
desc: (GNOME groupware) inherited from Ximian, where it fits in with their primatological theme (cue joke about the majority of Americans not believing in it and the rest not understanding it)

name: exfalso
desc: tag editor for quodlibet. "Ex falso quod libet" is Latin for "from a falsehood, whatever you please" (a principle of classical logic)

name: exim4
desc: version four of an MTA that was originally an EXperimental Internet Mailer

name: exo-utils
desc: the libexo support library for Xfce applications consists of extensions developed by os-cillation.de

name: expat
desc: the expat XML parser is so called because it's an English word that's close enough to X-pa(mumble)

name: eyes17
desc: Experiments for Young Engineers and Scientists

name: fcitx
desc: originally the free Chinese input toy for X; but that was never a very good name and has become increasingly inaccurate, so we are now permitted to understand it as standing for anything we like, such as maybe "friendly customizable interaction tool for UNIX", or maybe "flexible character indication technology for... xenography"

name: feersum
desc: (PSGI engine) a reference to the Iain M. Banks novel "Feersum Enjinn" ("fearsome engine")

name: fenics
desc: the FEniCS project provides computational software for finite element analysis, originally compiled at the University of Chicago (whose emblem is a phoenix)

name: ffmpeg
desc: (media player) "FF" as in Fast-Forward, MPEG as in the media format established by the Moving Picture Experts Group

name: fgetty
desc: Felix von Leitner's getty

name: figlet
desc: Frank, Ian, & Glenn's letters. Named by the original author for (1) a friend whose e-mail signature inspired the program, (2) another friend who contributed some code, and (3) himself

name: file-roller
desc: GNOME archive manager; the association with compression implies that it was named in the part of the anglophone world where people talk about "(road-)rollers" rather than always calling them "steamrollers"

name: firefox
desc: (mozilla-descended webbrowser) originally announced as Phoenix, then since there was already a trademarked browser by that name, Firebird... which it turned out was also taken. Their third pick was a literal translation of the Chinese name for Ailurus fulgens, the red (lesser) panda. Pay no attention to that logo, it's more closely related to seals than to foxes, and closer to skunks than to giant pandas. Then it spent a decade in Debian under yet another name

name: flite
desc: "festival lite", because it's a lightweight alternative to the Festival Speech Synthesis System (originally developed at the University of Edinburgh)

name: fop
desc: (XML converter) formatting objects processor

name: forg
desc: a Python-TK gopher client confusingly named as a Kermit reference - see the old explanation on its homepage. The gopher protocol itself got its name from the mascot of the University of Minnesota, and from the fact it runs file-fetching errands through a network of virtual tunnels.

name: fort77
desc: a front-end to invoke The IBM Mathematical FORmula TRANslating System, as standardized in the seventies (arguably 1978!)

name: fpc
desc: (the Free Pascal Compiler) "Free Pascal" is the particular free Pascal derived from FPK Pascal (named with its author's initials), and the language was named after the inventor of the mechanical calculator.

name: *fribidi*
desc: GNU FriBiDi is a free implementation of the Unicode Bi-directional Algorithm, to support writing systems like Hebrew and Arabic (which require both right-to-left and occasionally left-to-right text). Giving it the same vowel throughout may be to make it simpler for non-anglophones, or just funnier not to be confused with fribid, ITP #578563

name: fuse*
desc: some of these packages are more up-front than others about the fact it stands for filesystem-in-userspace, which is not so much an acronym as a pair of jargon terms smushed together. Maybe it would have been called u-mount if that wasn't already taken

name: futatabi
desc: (video server) Japanese for "again", because it does replays etc

name: fvwm
desc: nobody knows what the "F" stands for, but the most popular arbitrary retrofit is that it's the "feline" virtual window manager

name: g10k
desc: (Puppet environment and module deployment) no, it's not short for "gobbledigook", it's just a Go rewrite of r10k

name: gajim
desc: Gajim's A Jabber Instant Messenger (not to be confused with gaim - see pidgin)

name: gambas3
desc: (BASIC IDE) GAMBAS is a recursive acronym for "GAMBAS almost means BASIC", as well as being Spanish/Portuguese for "prawns" (hence the logo)

name: gamin
desc: francophone wordplay: first there was the File Alteration Monitor, then (because "fam" is short for "family") its child projects were called "marmot" and "gamin" (both of which mean something like "kid", "brat")

name: ganeti
desc: (VM-clusterizer) the FAQ has vanished, but apparently it's a distinctive nonsense-word

name: gawk
desc: GNU AWK - see mawk

name: gazebo*
desc: (robotics simulator) the next best thing to testing them outdoors

name: gcompris
desc: (educational games) another French pun: "G Compris" = "j'ai compris" = "I understand (have understood)"

name: gcp
desc: stands for Goffi's file CoPier, Goffi being the nickname of the author

name: geany
desc: (GTK IDE) something along the lines of Gtk-anythingyoulike, with the E just nudging it in the direction of "genie" (or judging by the FAQ's pronunciation guide, French "génie")

name: geeqie
desc: a fork of gqview (punning on "geeky") (but why "GQview" in the first place? Was it an app for reading GQ magazine??)

name: gforth
desc: GNU Forth, which would have been named FOURTH if IBM 1130s allowed six-letter names, since it claimed to be fourth-generation software (though not a 4GL in the later sense)

name: ghostscript
desc: a punning name for a GPLed alternative to Adobe PostScript

name: gigolo
desc: a GIO/GVfs filesystem connection manager, named this way because as a gigolo, it mounts what it is told to

name: gir*
desc: GIR is the GObject introspection repository; "type introspection" lets objects provide metadata about themselves, but the main influence on this name is probably the fact that "Gir" is an Invader Zim reference

name: git
desc: (distributed VCS) semi-arbitrary short word

name: gitalist
desc: (ex-package) web viewer for git based on Catalyst

name: gkermit
desc: GPLed client for the kermit protocol, which was named after the muppet but backronymed as "Kl10 Errorfree Reciprocal Microprocessor Interchange over TTY" a free kermit? should have been "permit"

name: gkrellm
desc: according to the vanished FAQ, it's short for GNU (or GTK) Krell Monitors (or meters), the Krell being the alien species featured in the movie "Forbidden Planet"

name: glance
desc: (OpenStack image service) a name associated with speed and the visual sense of the word "image"

name: glewlwyd
desc: (OAuth2 authentication server) in Welsh legend, King Arthur's gatekeeper

name: *glib*
desc: named after the non-GUI-specific code separated out from GTK+, where the G as usual stands indirectly for GNU; not to be confused with glibc AKA eglibc AKA libc6

name: glymur-*
desc: (JPEG2000 tools) named after a waterfall in Iceland. presumably as a (web media) "streaming" reference

name: gnat
desc: (the GCC Ada compiler) originally the GNU NYU (New York University) Ada(95) Translator (Ada being named in honor of "the first computer programmer", Ada Lovelace)

name: gnats
desc: (bug-tracker) not to be confused with the above: gnats are just GNU-themed bugs (or insects at any rate)

name: gnocchi-*
desc: (OpenStack Metering-as-a-Service) a thematic-naming pun on the OpenStack message queue called Marconi (deliberately confusing that with "macaroni") - see zaqar

name: gnome
desc: originally the GNU Network Object Model Environment, (was the reference to gnomes perhaps also a play on the fact that KDE depended on the non-DFSG-free Qt framework produced by Trolltech?) until that was judged not to match the project's objectives; now it doesn't stand for anything (and in particular there is no truth at all to the rumor that it now stands for "Gradually Narrowing Options Maximize Exasperation")

name: gnome-klotski
desc: a GNOME sliding block puzzle; from the Polish "klocki", "wooden blocks", and formerly known even more obscurely as gnotski

name: gnome-orca
desc: as the FAQ used to explain, named in the same tradition as previous screen-readers such as Flipper and Dolphin

name: gnome-sushi
desc: previewer for nautilus; presumably the idea is that you're eating raw cephalopod. (Strictly speaking sushi is a kind of rice, traditionally accompanied with seafood using a preparation method that takes a lot longer than simply cooking it) Not to be confused with the sushi which is a metapackage for a thematically named IRC suite though both sushis make a big deal of their dbus integration

name: gnome-tetravex
desc: a vexing GNOME puzzle played on a 4×4 grid; formerly known even more obscurely as gnotravex

name: gnumach
desc: (not to be confused with mach) GNU implementation of the MACH microkernel, which was originally jokingly named MUCK - "multi-user (or multiprocessor universal) communication kernel" - until it was misspelled by an Italian

name: gnuplot
desc: a graphing tool, but one that has absolutely nothing to do with GNU: "gnu" was just an arbitrary animal name that sounds like "new"

name: gnustep-*
desc: a GUI programming environment descended from NeXTStep (which came from NeXT Software, Inc.); meanwhile macOS is derived from OpenStep (and no, there's no Microsoft GooseStep)

name: gobby
desc: (GNOME collaborative editor) originally built around a library called libobby (linked with -lobby); the GUI was therefore named g-obby

name: golang
desc: (not an i18n package for goplay, or even connected to Google's Go-playing machine, which is mostly in C++) Google's Go programming language, which they seem to have given the shortest name they could find that was (a) cool and (b) Google-related

name: gprolog
desc: the GNU compiler for Prolog, which was so called as an abbreviation in French for "programmation en logique" (logic programming)

name: grace
desc: descended from xmgr (the X Motif GRapher) which was also for no obvious reason known as ACE/gr

name: grep
desc: Global Regular Expression Print

name: grim
desc: (Wayland screenshotter) grab image

name: groff
desc: the GNU replacement for the text formatters troff (typesetter roff) and nroff ("new" as of 1979); "roff" is a contraction of "run-off" as in "run off a hard copy"

name: gromacs
desc: (Molecular Dynamics computation system) nothing to do with groff or emacs; it's the Groningen (NL) machine for chemical simulation

name: gross
desc: mailserver for graylisting of suspicious sources

name: guacamole
desc: (web VNC system) arbitrary word and near-miss for a cool animal name

name: gudhi-utils
desc: "Geometry Understanding In Higher Dimensions", folded through hyperspace into GUDHI as in the Marathi "guḍhī pāḍavā" festival

name: guetzli
desc: a (JPEG) compression tool named after a Swiss bakery product (cf. zopfli); in this case biscuits

name: guile-*
desc: backronymed as the GNU Ubiquitous Intelligent Language for Extensions, but mainly a pun; it's an interpreter/virtual machine for the language "scheme", which was originally named "schemer", in the tradition of lisp-derivatives like "planner" and "conniver"

name: gummiboot
desc: (ex-package) (UEFI bootloader) a German pun (cf. u-boot) - a Gummiboot is a rubber dinghy; simple, portable, and easy to deploy

name: gweled
desc: a GTK+ clone of "Bejeweled", punningly named in Welsh ("gweled" means "vision")

name: hadoop-*
desc: (ex-package) surprisingly doesn't stand for high-availability distributed object-oriented programming; it was stolen from the name the programmer's son gave to a toy elephant (an arbitrary animal with convenient undertones of "lumbering but lovable")

name: halibut
desc: (doc-formatter) "Historical reasons. It's probably better not to ask."

name: handlebars
desc: a JavaScript tool for handling templates, designed to be a compatible replacement for mustache, which is so-called because it uses lots of mustache-like {{braces}}

name: haserl
desc: lightweight CGI wrapper system; a Bavarian word for "bunny" (so another semi-arbitrary animal)

name: heat-*
desc: (OpenStack orchestration service) as in atmospheric dynamics and cloud creation

name: heimdal-*
desc: free implementation of Kerberos 5; named after another mythological watch-keeper (in this case a Norse god)

name: herbstluftwm
desc: (tiling window manager) it's not a random stack of letters, it's a beautiful German word! Herbst-Luft-WM, the Fall-Air (or should that be Autumn-Breeze?) Window Manager, is so called because the author liked the sound of the MUA "wanderlust" AKA wl

name: hesiod
desc: a name service for storing system databases; another classical reference from Project Athena - Hesiod was biographer to the gods

name: ho22bus
desc: vocabulary learning software for and by non-native English-speakers; the name is short for "honorificabilitudinitatibus", the longest word in Shakespeare, and has nothing to do with any other sort of bus

name: hotot
desc: (ex-package) (micro-blogging Twitter/Identica client) named after a breed of dwarf rabbit (which is named after a place in Normandy) (pronounced "oh-TOE")

name: hugs
desc: (Haskell interpreter) Haskell user's gofer system, Haskell being named after the logician Haskell Curry (<homer>mmm, curry</homer>)

name: hugin
desc: (panoramic photo stitcher) named after one of the two ravens of the Norse god Odin (cf. the otherwise unconnected package munin). The name is Old Norse for "thought"

name: hunspell
desc: a spellchecker that was originally specific to Hungarian

name: hylafax-*
desc: the HylaFAX telecopying server (renamed from FlexFAX to avoid trademark issues) is named after a genus of tree-frog because it makes deafening croaking noises?

name: i2c-tools
desc: I-squared-C, meaning "Inter-Integrated Circuit", is a hardware bus protocol, which gets us a little closer to guessing that it means "tools for reading from hardware health-monitoring sensors"

name: i3
desc: designed as the successor to wmii, this is the third generation of improvements to this kind of window manager and stands for Improved Improved Improved, shortened to i3

name: iagno
desc: it admits to being similar to Go (not that go) and derived from Reversi; but the key to understanding the name is that it's "GNOME iago", because the name of the trademarked version is Othello, and when you metaphorically invert Othello (in the play of the same name) you get Iago

name: icebox
desc: (now a virtual package) middleware development framework using ZeroC's Internet Communications Engine (2003)

name: icecast2
desc: streaming audio server, a cool (?) free clone of Shoutcast (1998; I'd have thought a "rogue shoutcast" would be an "outcast")

name: icedax
desc: free fork of cdda2wav for cdrkit (see also wodim); supposedly the Incredible Digital Audio Extractor, but note that this fork happened just as iceweasel was being renamed

name: icedtea-*
desc: free version of OpenJDK (see Java), which couldn't use that trademarked name (2006 again)

name: iceweasel
desc: temporary branding-free microfork of Mozilla firefox; for background see Wikipedia (plus iceape, icedove; all renamed 2004-2006)

name: icewm
desc: Win95-alike window manager, named "on a very hot day" (in 1997)

name: icinga
desc: a fork of NAGIOS which was careful to pick a name that's definitely untrademarked. "Icinga" means "it browses" in Zulu (where "C" represents a tutting sound)

name: idle
desc: officially an Integrated DeveLopment Environment for Python (rather than being named after Monty Python's Eric Idle). Predated eric

name: inotify-tools
desc: inotify is a Linux filesystem-monitoring interface, but what does the "I" stand for? It replaced dnotify, where the "D" definitely stood for "Directory"; so the answer is probably "Inode". But even Dennis Ritchie wasn't sure what the "I" in "Inode" stood for! The traditional guess was "Index", but it's only a guess

name: insserv
desc: reading between the lines of its man page's EXIT CODES section, "install services", i.e. "add daemons to the SysV init system"

name: iptables
desc: tool for configuring the Linux kernel's handling of IPv4 packets; the package description does manage to mention the word "firewall", but never fully explains the package's name. There's no rows-and-columns structure involved; it's just that each firewall rule is an "IP chain" (as used by the old ipchains) and the chains are grouped into sets called "IP tables" (it's nothing to do with ipting everything iptable, either)

name: ironic-*
desc: (OpenStack provisioning server) a nice obvious pun on bare metal

name: irssi
desc: phonological pun (not necessarily in English) on ircII, "Internet Relay Chat client, second edition"

name: ispell
desc: (spellchecker) nothing to do with iBooks! It was the first interactive successor to UNIX spell

name: isso
desc: (web commenting system) German online abbreviation for "ich schrei sonst" ("otherwise I'll scream")

name: istanbul
desc: (ex-package) (desktop recorder) disappointingly this  was never known as constantinople; it was named after a particular football match ("Liverpool's fifth European Cup triumph in Istanbul on May 25th 2005")

name: iw
desc: a package (and CLI tool) that might have been called ieee802.11-standard-wireless-network-interface-device-configurator-utility; it replaces iwconfig, which was like ifconfig with a "W" for "wireless" jammed in seemingly at random (and compare the similarly basic iproute2 command ip)

name: jami
desc: (phone AV/chat platform) "inspired by a Swahili word that means 'community'" though my dictionary says that's "jamii", and "jami" means "jam"

name: java-*
desc: the programming language is named after (a variety of) the raw material that mathematicians turn into theorems (this by the way was originally a pun about rather than by Erdős in either German or Hungarian, which use the same word for "theorem" and "leftover coffee grounds")

name: javascript-*
desc: a programming language announced as a web technology just as Java was becoming successful in that field, and widely suspected of being named as a deliberate ploy to ride on its coat-tails, though it had been known as "Mocha" very early in its development

name: jenkins*
desc: a fork of Oracle's software building/testing infrastructure, Hudson™; both are vaguely butlery names, and Jenkins has the bonus of beginning with J-for-java Jeeves was taken

name: jerry
desc: Chess GUI; thematically named by its German developer after the existing "Fritz" - both being wartime nicknames for Germans

name: jetty*
desc: (Java servlet engine) the FAQ mentions several reasons (but skips "it's a safe place to launch things")

name: jffnms
desc: (ex-package) not very appropriately a Just For Fun Network Management System

name: joe
desc: Joe's Own Editor by Joseph H. Allen (whose first name is often abbreviated Joe)

name: jovie
desc: formerly kttsd (KDE Text-To-Speech Daemon) but renamed after the developer's daughter

name: jpnevulator
desc: originally created as a Jackpot Navigator emulator (for interfacing with slot machines), it transformed into a serial sniffer that is able to send data on a serial line too. Giving credit to this first use, the name is some sort of strange mash up

name: jupp
desc: fork of JOE named after the author's friend Josef, which can be abbreviated Jupp or Sepp depending on the part of Germany you live in - the latter more common in Bavaria

name: k3b
desc: (KDE CD/DVD-burner) the "K" is obvious, but it's not "K-times-three B" (because that's a KKK-burner); it's not "K[...three letters...]B" (because that's a kebab); it's "a K and three Bs", meaning "KDE Burn, Baby, Burn"

name: *kafka
desc: no, Amazon Kafka isn't named in the expectation that it will someday metamorphose into a single enormous bug; the author says it's "a system optimized for writing"

name: kadu
desc: a KDE-based client for the gadu-gadu Instant Messaging protocol (popular in Poland, where "gadu-gadu" is "chit-chat")

name: kamailio-*
desc: (SIP proxy) was called "OpenSER", then dodged a trademark with the Hawaiian word "kama‘ilio" = "talk/converse"

name: kanla
desc: (ex-package) (outage-spotter) you might guess from the logo that it means "eye", but you probably wouldn't guess the source language: Lojban

name: karbon
desc: (KOffice/Calligra vector graphics package) originally known as Karbon14 after the isotope used in radiocarbon-dating (for some reason... Successor of Kontour, formerly unwisely known as KIllustrator)

name: kde-*
desc: originally a replacement for the Common Desktop Environment with a Kooler arbitrary initial letter. However, these days for branding reasons the desktop environment is officially called Plasma, and KDE is just the developer community, so presumably it doesn't stand for anything. (Meanwhile, following Plasma's states-of-matter theme, the hardware support framework is provided by libsolid)

name: kephra
desc: (text editor) named after "the scarab god (neter) of ancient Egypt", since that deity created himself and this is software that the programmers use to produce new versions of itself. But while "neter" may be the Ancient Egyptian for "deity", "kephra" appears to be a typo for "Khepra"...

name: keystone
desc: (OpenStack authentication service) a crucial building-block, and as a bonus the word sounds as if it means something security-related rather than just a lump of masonry

name: kgb-client
desc: KGB is a bot relaying VCS commits to IRC notifications, successor to CIA, which was "a brainless entity designed to keep an eye on subversion". Not related to kgb the file-compressor.

name: kismet
desc: (wireless sniffer) "The word itself means Fate or Destiny. While I wish I could make up some smart comment about picking it because Kismet will ultimately uncover every active wireless network in the area, really I just needed a name and was clicking through a thesaurus and liked the sound."

name: klibc-utils
desc: tools built with an alternate C library specialized for use at boot-time - the "K" is for (the Linux) Kernel

name: kodi
desc: the media center formerly known as xbmc, XBox Media Center, or (even earlier) Xbox Media Player. That name became misleading and awkward, so they picked one that (among other considerations) is vaguely connected to the word "code"

name: kodos
desc: (ex-package) regexp debugger named as an arbitrary Simpsons reference (Kodos being one of the UFO aliens)

name: konqueror
desc: (KDE file manager and web browser) the name is a play on the names of its competitors at the time: after visits from a Navigator and an Explorer, the next to arrive is the Conqueror

name: kopano-*
desc: groupware; formerly known as zarafa (which means "giraffe", but was also the name of a famous zoo giraffe). Continuing the same arbitrary ungulate connection, "Kopano" is "united" in Tswana (as spoken in Botswana), and the name of a baby giraffe at Dallas zoo

name: kopete
desc: KDE chat client; copete in Spanish is literally "tuft of hair", but Chilean slang for "a drink with your friends" (so kopete translates as either kuiff or kuaff)

name: krb5-*
desc: squeezed name for "MIT Kerberos version five"; Kerberos was the watchdog of the Greek underworld (also known in Latinized form as Cerberus), so it's a natural label for the network authentication protocol originally designed for Project Athena

name: krita
desc: KOffice/Calligra graphics package; in Swedish, "krita" means "chalk/crayon" and "K-rita" is "K-draw"; but if that's not enough justification, "krita" is also Sanskrit for "perfect" (Formerly known as Krayon. Compare also the obsolete KOffice component names "Kivio" = approximately "K-Visio" and "Kugar" = just an arbitrary animal misspelled with a "K"?)

name: krusader
desc: a two-panel file manager in the tradition of Midnight Commander, with a "K" for KDE. All the names like kommander, kontroller, and kaptain had already been claimed, so this app has ended up with one that won't make it popular in the Middle East (though there's no sign of a korporal, kolonel, kommodore, kommissar, konsul, or kaiser)

name: kupfer
desc: a launcher described as "in the style of" Mac OS X's Quicksilver. "Kupfer" is German for "copper", so apparently it's just a thematic chemical element and the K doesn't indicate a particular desktop allegiance

name: latexila
desc: a LaTeX editor; pun with LaTeX and tequila, « la tequila » meaning “the tequila” in French

name: lazarus
desc: an IDE for Pascal; a "back from the dead" fork of the Megido project (which was an attempt to clone Delphi, which was in turn "where you go to talk to an Oracle")

name: ldap-*
desc: the lightweight directory access protocol provided a "telephone directory" system that was lightweight in terms of bandwidth usage compared to the X.500 DAP

name: leela-zero
desc: (go-playing engine) "Leela" is a Futurama "one eye" reference; the author already had an engine with that name before this reimplementation of AlphaGo-Zero

name: leiningen
desc: Clojure project tool; a reference to the short story "Leiningen Versus the Ants"

name: lektor
desc: (website CMS) German for "reader/literary editor"

name: lemonldap-ng-uwsgi-app
desc: a uWSGI server (Web Server Gateway Interface, but is it u-for-Unbit or mu-for-micro?) for the Next Generation version of this online LDAP server... a fork so old that all trace of the original has faded from the web, probably taking with it the reason for the citrusy name

name: lesstif*
desc: (ex-package) first there was the Open Software Foundation's proprietary User Environment Component, which was named Motif in an in-house name-the-GUI-widget-toolkit competition and went on to become a UNIX industry standard. That had an LGPLed fork named LessTif ("less" being the opposite of "mo'") and a just-good-enough-for-nonfree fork called OpenMotif; but now Motif itself has gone GPL and lesstif is no more

name: libbobcat*
desc: (C++ toolkit) Frank Brokken's own base classes and templates

name: libbonobo*
desc: deprecated CORBA precursor to dbus. Developed by Ximian and named like most of their products with an arbitrary word out of primatology

name: libc6
desc: obviously, the main system libraries for the C programming language, version six; the source package is called eglibc, meaning the fork of the standard GNU libc originally developed for embedded systems. But why "C"? First (in sixties Cambridge) there was CPL, the Combined (i.e. collaboratively developed) Programming Language - though some accounts say the C was originally for Christopher (Strachey). Then there was BCPL (Bootstrap or later Basic CPL); next that got stripped down to "B", then reimplemented as just "C". Self-proclaimed successors to C include "C++" and "D".

name: libcaca*
desc: see caca-utils

name: libcairo*
desc: see cairo*

name: libexpat*
desc: see expat

name: libfribidi*
desc: see *fribidi*

name: libglib*
desc: see *glib*

name: libharfbuzz*
desc: (Unicode-capable text shaping library) a calque of "OpenType" in the original developer's native Persian (plus an untranslatable pun)

name: libklibc*
desc: see klibc-utils

name: libmotif*
desc: see lesstif*

name: libnepomuk*
desc: a "networked environment for personal, ontology-based management of unified knowledge" (as part of a "semantic desktop"); the word also happens to be a town in the Czech republic

name: libpango*
desc: see *pango*

name: libsoup
desc: was originally a library for SOAP, which sounds like "soup" when pronounced with certain accents (ref)

name: libwayland*
desc: see wayland

name: libxerces*
desc: (Apache C++ XML-handling toolkit) named after King Xerces, AKA Ahasuerus, AKA Khshayarsha I, AKA Xerxes the Great of Persia (son-in-law of Cyrus), perhaps indirectly via the extinct Californian butterfly the Xerces Blue. is there any reason behind this beyond "begins with X"?

name: lsb-base
desc: expands to "Linux Standard Base base", which is a little confusing when it's a required package even on Debian GNU/kFreeBSD

name: lsh-server
desc: an SSH2 daemon, but the significance of the "L" is long lost (Lysator? Liberty? Left?)

name: lua*
desc: Brazilian programming language inspired by the Simple Object Language (in Portuguese, "sol" is "sun" and "lua" is "moon"). "Linguagem para Usuarios de Aplicação" (Language for Application Users) is just a jokey backronym; writing it as LUA is now considered a Lua Uppercase Accident.

name: lynx
desc: a punning animal name. Pre-Stretch the package was confusingly called lynx-cur, a relic of the days when there were separate packages based on the current and stable versions

name: lyx
desc: this LaTeX document processor was originally named LyriX (which apparently is just something that sounded good and vaguely resembled LaTeX) but that turned out to be taken, so it changed to something that let it keep the .lyx file extension

name: lzop
desc: (compression tool) the name may look like a compressed version of LZOzip, but officially it's the Lempel–Ziv–Oberhumer Packer

name: m4
desc: (macro processor) GNU M4 is indeed a successor to m3, but that was seemingly so named not because there had ever been an m2 but because it was a macro-processor for the AP-3 minicomputer. Some short command-names (such as cp, df, or ls) may function to save ordinary CLI users the effort of typing anything longer, but m4 rarely needs to be invoked manually (it's just called by automated build systems). The two-letter name is a mark of its age and importance

name: mach
desc: (ex-package) tool to make a chroot for an RPM-based distro (not to be confused with GNU MACH or with the ATI GPU). The word "mach" also happens to be German for "make", and the surname of a German physicist who gave his name to various cool things

name: magnum-*
desc: (OpenStack containers-as-a-service) because a magnum can be a container for a lot of champagne, and/or bullets or maybe  "Magnum A.P.I." is an eighties TV reference

name: mahimahi
desc: (network emulation toolkit) mahi-mahi is the Hawaiian name for the creature better known elsewhere as the dolphinfish or dorado - apparently just a random animal with no intended implication that it might get tangled in your net (Maybe it was named in a restaurant?)

name: mandos
desc: (encrypted-rootfs server) nothing to do with man or DOS; a rather obscure Tolkien reference

name: manila-*
desc: (OpenStack filesystem as a service) punning on "manila folder", the kind of file container originally made from manila hemp

name: mantis
desc: (ex-package) a bugtracker named after a bug-catching insect (though since it's web-based, why not a spider?)

name: marco
desc: (metacity fork for MATE, thematically named in Spanish) "frame" nothing to do with Mr Polo

name: mariadb-*
desc: non-Oracle-owned fork of MySQL by the original developers, including Monty Widenius, whose younger daughter is named Maria

name: mate-*
desc: (fork of GNOME 2, so often misleadingly written MATE) nothing to do with sex or death: it's just named after the South American beverage, presumably to fit Linux Mint's "herbs and spices" theme - cf. cinnamon

name: mathopd
desc: (ex-package) (web server) from the developer's IRC nick (according to the old FAQ, now forgotten even by archive.org)

name: maven
desc: (Java build management tool) a Yiddish word for "expert" or "wisdom-gatherer" adopted into US English; the idea is that maven is a central place for build-information

name: mawk
desc: Mike Brennan's implementation of the pattern scanning and text processing language AWK, which is named after its authors - Alfred Aho, Peter Weinberger, and Brian Kernighan

name: mc
desc: this file-manager is a clone of "NC", Norton Commander (yes, it's that old); its full name is "GNU Midnight Commander". Okay, that explains the "C". But what's so Midnightish about it - why wasn't it called, say, "console commander"? Either there's an obscure cultural reference here or maybe version 0.0 was called "Nocturnal Commander"

name: melange
desc: (ex-package) (former OpenStack IP-address-manager) first introduced with a "Dune" reference ("the IPs must flow")

name: menhir
desc: (OCaml parsergenerator) Breton for standing stone; cf morbig the Old Celtic connection would make more sense if the language was called Ogam-L...

name: mercurial
desc: created during the bitkeeper troubles with the Linux kernel, and named in honor of BitMover CEO Larry McVoy (since it can mean "fickle"). Also because it conveniently abbreviates to "hg" (chemical symbol of mercury), and because it fits the existing namespace of selenic.com nothing to do with Merkle hash trees

name: mesa-utils
desc: mesa is an implementation of the OpenGL 3D graphics system; the developer recalls "The name Mesa just popped into my head one day. SGI had asked me not to use the terms ''Open'' or ''GL'' in the project name and I didn't want to make up a new acronym"

name: meson
desc: (Python build system) not a typo for "mason"; they were thinking of calling it "gluon", but this was the closest name still unclaimed

name: metacity
desc: an otherwise deliberately uncool window-manager named after an arbitrary cool (made-up) word - "Metacity is not a meta-City as in an urban center, but rather Meta-ness as in the state of being meta, i.e. metacity : meta as opacity : opaque. Also it may have something to do with the Meta key on UNIX keyboards." Though surely metacity would be the state of being metacious?

name: mg
desc: (text editor) originally "MicroGnuEmacs" (there was already a "MicroEmacs"), but since it doesn't actually have anything to do with GNU the developer was asked to rename it, and chose somewhat eccentrically to make it a MilliGnu (well, I suppose PicoEditor was taken)

name: mhonarc
desc: Mail-to-HTML archiving tool, which explains most but not quite enough of it

name: mimedefang
desc: a general-purpose email filter named after its original specialty: making safe ("de-fanging") message attachments (MIME = Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions)

name: mistral-*
desc: (OpenStack business workflow service) named after a seasonal wind - i.e. a predictably scheduled "flow" of air

name: mksh
desc: the MirBSD Korn Shell (after ksh88/ksh93 which are named for their author David G. Korn); from one of the more recent BSD derivatives

name: mlocate
desc: a locate implementation where the "M" stands for "merging"

name: *moinmoin*
desc: the name of the MoinMoin wiki-engine is taken from a Dutch/Low Saxon greeting roughly equivalent to "aloha", presumably chosen because (like lots of wiki-engine names) it's informal and repetitive. It has nothing to do with the Nigerian steamed bean pudding of the same name

name: molly-guard
desc: named after the plexiglass covers used to protect the Big Red Switch on University of Illinois servers from marauding toddlers

name: mongodb
desc: an unfortunate name in various Germanic languages, but it's intended to imply that it's a database system that scales to humongous sizes

name: monkeysphere
desc: this community-driven cryptographic certification framework is named in reference to Dunbar's Number, an estimate of the maximum number of peers a primate can effectively keep track of while negotiating social relationships

name: mono-*
desc: .NET-compatible programming platform; it was first developed by Ximian, and "mono" is Spanish for "monkey", so it's yet another semi-arbitrary primate name

name: morbig
desc: (POSIX shell parser) Breton (cf. menhir) for "oystercatcher", a picky eater

name: mozilla-*
desc: originally Netscape's in-house codename/mascot for what they hoped would be a "Mosaic killer" (with perhaps a hint of self-deprecation); nowadays the "moz" part is often used as an abbreviation for Mozilla(-based browser)

name: mozo
desc: (alacarte fork for MATE, thematically named in Spanish) "servant" or "waiter" (a menu-handler) nothing to do with mozilla

name: mrd6
desc: multicast routing daemon for IPv6

name: muffin
desc: a fork of Mutter for the cinnamon desktop - a name close in form to the former and associated in meaning with the latter

name: munin
desc: (network monitor) named after one of the two ravens of the Norse god Odin (cf. the otherwise unconnected package hugin). The name is Old Norse for "mind" or "memory"

name: murano-*
desc: (OpenStack application catalog) named (arbitrarily?) after a set of islands in Venice famous for glassmaking

name: mutt
desc: a self-deprecatory animal-name close to "MUA" (and maybe "TTY"?). It was forked as neomutt when development slowed down, but has now learned some new tricks

name: mutter-*
desc: GNOME window manager; a derivative of Metacity using the Clutter graphics library for compositing (and libclutter is so called because... it's a Canvas Library that lets you fill the screen with all sorts of complicated junk?)

name: mysql-*
desc: a Structured Query Language server named after the original developer's daughter "My" (cf. also mariadb)

name: nagios*
desc: a network monitor, formerly known as NetSaint, but to avoid trademark issues uninformatively renamed as "Nagios Ain't Gonna Insist On Sainthood". Indeed it's gone rather out of its way not to infringe: "HAGIOS" would have worked equally well for that recursive acronym and would have been the New Testament Greek for "saint"...

name: nano
desc: allegedly, nano's another editor; a smaller and for a long time freer clone of pico, the pine composer (that is, the text-editor for the pine MUA - see alpine)

name: nautilus
desc: a file-system-navigating shell, named after a non-arbitrary animal: the shelled cephalopod whose name means "sailor"

name: ncompress
desc: new-in-the-nineties version of the standard UNIX file compressing utility, using the (then) patent-encumbered LZW algorithm (unlike gzip's compatibility version); see zlib1g

name: ncurses-*
desc: a new-in-the-nineties free fork of the curses terminal (and cursor) control library used for Text User Interfaces (aptly named for the activity you’re sure to do when programming with libcurses)

name: nedit
desc: originally the Nirvana Text Editor in 1991, so maybe not a direct reference to the religious sort of nirvana

name: nemiver
desc: a GNOME debugger; verlan (French backslang) for "vermin"

name: nemo
desc: file manager for the cinnamon desktop, but with no spicy connection in the name (and not a Pixar reference); this is a fork ("steering in a new direction") of Nautilus, and Nemo was the Latin and/or Greek nom de guerre of the commander (cf. mc) of the fictional submarine of that name

name: nethack-*
desc: not a net-hacking tool or even a game played over the net. It was a game (of hacking a trail through a virtual dungeon) that was distributed and cooperatively developed over USENET

name: netpbm
desc: commandline image manipulation tools using portable bitmap and related formats; like the above (or indeed NetBSD) it uses "net" to mean roughly "maintained by an open, widely distributed group of contributors"

name: neutron-*
desc: (OpenStack networking service) a similarly science-y albeit slightly less cloudy name to replace quantum after a trademark clash with the hardware manufacturers, not any of the several "Quantum software" companies

name: newsboat
desc: (RSS feedreader) a fork of newsbeuter, which was a German pun on "hunter-gatherer"

name: nginx
desc: (web server, pronounced as "engine-X" and not as a rhyme for "minx") because it powers your web site and brand-names sound cooler if they end in X. The package nginx-naxsi-ui is especially cryptic: it's the nginx anti-XSS-SQL-injection module's user interface (Cross-Site Scripting is abbreviated XSS because calling it CSS would be too confusing - though since they needn't involve any "cross-site" or "scripting", it's a pity they didn't just switch to calling them "client-mediated exploits" or something...)

name: ninka
desc: (software license manager) Japanese for "permission, license"

name: nmh
desc: new-in-the-nineties version of the MH message handler (a CLI mailreader toolkit dating back to the seventies)

name: nnn
desc: "Nnn is Not Noice". Remember the file manager noice? Me neither

name: nodejs
desc: (JavaScript platform) originally web.js, but renamed to node.js to imply it could function as any other kind of network component. Not to be confused with the amateur packet radio program ax25-node, formerly known as node

name: notmuch
desc: (mail indexer) among other things, it's the answer to sup

name: nova-*
desc: (OpenStack Compute service) after NASA's similar "Nebula" (which was named from the Latin for "cloud")

name: ntfs-3g
desc: "NT file system support, third generation" - a fork, since re-merged, of ntfsprogs; but when was "-2G"? ("Windows NT" has a confused history, but is officially meaningless)

name: nvi
desc: new-in-the-nineties version of vi, q.v.

name: nwall
desc: new-in-the-nineties version of wall, the utility for writing messages to all logged-in users

name: nwrite
desc: new-in-the-nineties version of write (A.K.A. bsd-write)

name: nyquist
desc: music-score language named after phone engineer Harry Nyquist, who discovered noise

name: nyx
desc: (TOR monitor) goddess of night, a short and memorable classical reference

name: obex-data-server
desc: the object exchange protocol is used for sending stuff over IrDA/Bluetooth, and has nothing to do with the "obex" which is part of the brainstem

name: obnam
desc: (ex-package) (backup system) short for "obligatory name", in the sense that it had to have one, and this arbitrary string will do

name: ocaml
desc: objective caml (originally the punning "categorical abstract machine language"; and let's not forget that "objective" in this sense is also a play on words)

name: ocsigenserver
desc: ocaml web server; a homophone of "oxygen" (in French; it could have been "ocxygène", but this version is 7-bit clean). Its scripting module eliom is a similar play on "hélium"

name: octave*
desc: (MATLAB-like number-crunching language) GNU Octave isn't named after the musical scale - it's in honor of a chemical engineering professor famed for his calculating skills, Octave Levenspiel

name: oidentd
desc: Ojnk Software Design identification daemon

name: openjade
desc: a contribution-friendly fork of jade, which never officially stood for anything, though early reports were that it was "James (Clark)'s awesome DSSSL engine" (DSSSL being "Document Style Semantics and Specification Language" - in other words an SGML/XML document formatting standard)

name: openstack-*
desc: (cloud computing architecture) named in terms of the stack metaphor originally applied to "layered" network protocols; but there's a hint of a "cloud layers" pun here (after all, its proprietary rivals include "CloudStack")

name: openswan
desc: (ex-package) as in StrongSwan and FreeS/WAN (which is punctuated a bit more transparently), "swan" indicates "Secure Wide Area Network"

name: orage
desc: originally named xfcalendar, but switched to the French for "thunderstorm"; this may be a pun on "agenda organizer" in one language or another, or it may be because Mozilla Thunderbird's calendaring extension is called "lightning"

name: oregano
desc: GNOME circuit simulator, named thematically after the Simulation Program with Integrated Circuit Emphasis; it can't hurt that this one has a "G" in it

name: orthanc-*
desc: medical database server; a Tolkienian wizard's home

name: owl
desc: (ex-package) client for Zephyr, which was the original Instant Messaging protocol for Project Athena - Zephyr being the Greek god of the west wind and the owl being the (wind-borne) mascot of Athena (the "staying up all night" part might be relevant too). This package has approximately zero users, but there's also a fork called barnowl which has at least a few

name: pan
desc: is now too embarrassed to admit that it was claiming to be a pimp-ass newsreader (which for obscure reasons is a boast rather than an insult)

name: *pango*
desc: a cross-language hybrid: "pan" (Greek for "every") plus "go" (not quite Japanese for "language")

name: parole
desc: in French this doesn't mean "getting out of prison by giving your word of honor that you'll behave", it's just "(spoken) word", and thus a reasonable name for a simple media player

name: parrot
desc: (now appropriately an ex-package) (common virtual machine for dynamic languages) named after a historic April Fool's hoax that came true

name: passepartout
desc: (ex-package) desktop publishing app. Originally "Framer" (compare FrameMaker), then renamed to something more interesting: a "passepartout" is a kind of cardboard frame that you put around watercolor paintings. (In the original French it also means "skeleton key", but that doesn't necessarily mean it installs a back door on your computer)

name: patroni
desc: a fork of "Governor" thematically named after various related pieces of software with names that generally mean "boss" (except isn't the word they were aiming for spelled "patrone"?)

name: pcmanfm
desc: (file manager) because the main developer's nickname is "PCMan"

name: pekwm
desc: (window manager) the original developer had the pseudonym "pekdon", which means "pointing device" in Swedish (more literally "pick tool"), so presumably it's that and not the brand of spamlike canned meat

name: perl
desc: the expansions "Practical Extraction and Report Language" and "Pathologically Eclectic Rubbish Lister" are backronyms; it started (very briefly) as Pearl, then got shortened to something more distinctive

name: pfstools
desc: utilities for handling files in what they decided at the last minute to call portable floatmap streams format

name: phonon
desc: (KDE multimedia framework) in physics a phonon is a sort of unit of sound energy, and presumably in this case it's traveling through Plasma

name: php5
desc: originally "personal home page"; now redefined as the recursive "PHP hypertext preprocessor"

name: php5-suhosin
desc: (ex-package) (security hardening patch) Suhosin is Korean for "guardian angel" (or maybe "divine protection"; but the package now looks distinctly godforsaken)

name: pidgin
desc: trademark-dodging rename of gaim, the GTK+ AOL Instant Messenger; now named as a common medium of communication. Uses the libpurple protocol plugin library

name: pike*
desc: programming language, derived from µLPC (micro-Lars-Pensjö-C) but given "a more pronouncable and commercially viable name". (sic) The logo implies they were thinking of the fish rather than the polearm

name: pinfo
desc: Przemek's Info Viewer

name: ping
desc: named after the sonar pulse; "packet Internet groper" is a backronym

name: pinto
desc: (Perl module repository tool) named for the programmer's son

name: pitivi
desc: (video editor) the name comes from "Epitech" (the college where its developer was studying) plus (a franglais spelling of) "T.V."

name: pluma
desc: (gedit fork for MATE, thematically named in Spanish) "feather/quill/pen"

name: pluxml
desc: (XML-based blog) French portmanteau of plume (feather, as in light-as-a) and XML

name: plymouth
desc: (graphical boot splash) probably named after one of the Plymouths that were stepping-stones in the anglophone colonization of the new world

name: po-debconf
desc: there has never been a Debian Conference on the river Po. This is a tool for handling .po files (that is, gettext Portable Object message-catalogs) for debconf templates

name: pocketsphinx
desc: a version designed for embedded use of the SPHINX speech recognition system, initially developed at Carnegie Mellon University in the eighties and named in the same tradition as the seventies CMU systems "DRAGON" and "HARPY". Not related to the Python documentation system python-sphinx; neither of these are claiming to be like the sphinx of classical myth whose diet was people who had failed to solve its riddles.

name: polari
desc: (GNOME IRC client) from the name of the cant traditionally used in various underground subcultures in the UK

name: poppler-*
desc: (PDF renderer fork of XPDF) a Futurama reference, completely arbitrary except perhaps for the fact it begins with "P"

name: postfix
desc: (MTA) apparently an arbitrary word with "post" in it

name: postgresql-*
desc: a Structured Query Language server which is the successor to the Ingres project, which started as an INteractive Graphic[s] [and] REtrieval System (sources differ when it comes to the bracketed elements) Mind you, if "Ingres" was intended as a reference to the French painter, that would imply it's meant to be pronounced [ɛ̃ɡʁ], roughly ENG-grr

name: potrace
desc: nothing to do with .po files or pot-racing (that's dopewars); it "outlines" bitmap images as PostScript vector images using a polygon-based tracer

name: praat
desc: (speech analysis app) Dutch for "talk"

name: pragha
desc: lightweight music player named after a friend's band

name: prayer
desc: (IMAP-based webmail server) derived from the Web IMAP/NNTP Gateway (as in "on a wing and a prayer")

name: prey
desc: a mechanism for tracking stolen computers; but is it claiming that it preys on things or is it an antipredatory countermeasure? at least they've changed the confusing logo: it's now an actual bird of prey, not a scavenger

name: primus
desc: (NVidia Optimus support) see bumblebee

name: procps
desc: utilities that use data from procfs, including the process status tool ps, which originally didn't

name: prometheus
