desc: monitoring system for people who aren't scared of divine vengeance, or just don't overthink their classical references (At least it didn't get called Procrustes)

name: propellor
desc: (CMS using haskell and git) "The name is because propellor ensures that a system is configured with the desired properties, and also because it kind of pulls system configuration along after it. And you may not want to stand too close." (Though this doesn't explain the unorthodox spelling of "propeller"!)

name: psi
desc: an Instant Messaging client with a name taken from parapsychology, which had an appropriately specious official etymology (was the Telepathy/Empathy messaging framework named independently?)

name: pstack
desc: displays a process's stack (the data structure storing subroutine return addresses)

name: pulseaudio
desc: (sound server) formerly Polypaudio, but renamed to something a bit cooler and more music-related with the same initials

name: pump
desc: (BOOTP/DHCP client) because "pumps", like boots, are footwear - at least in some parts of England; elsewhere they may be called "plimsolls" or "sneakers"

name: putty
desc: (cross-platform SSH client) officially meaningless

name: python
desc: is of course a Monty Python reference

name: python-django
desc: see *django*

name: python-dulwich
desc: a somewhat obscure Monty Python reference: "Dulwich takes its name from the area in London where the friendly Mr. and Mrs. Git once attended a cocktail party"

name: python-kafka
desc: see *kafka

name: python-moinmoin
desc: see *moinmoin*

name: python-six
desc: (Python 2/Python 3 compatibility library) because 6 is 2*3 (and 2+3 was taken)

name: python-theano
desc: (mathematical compiler) named after Theano of Croton, AKA Mrs Pythagoras

name: python-twisted
desc: see *twisted*

name: python-urwid
desc: (console UI tools) the FAQ suggests an interpretation ("ur" = German for "primal" + widgets) but also implies it's a retrofit

name: qemu
desc: written QEMU (as if it was a four-word initialism), but it's just a "quick emulator"

name: quadrapassel
desc: formerly gnometris (i.e. GNOME Tetris), but trademark-dodgingly renamed as some sort of thesaurus-mangled version of "four-block"

name: quagga
desc: the earlier routing daemon zebra may have been an Arbitrary Ungulate; when that stopped being developed, its successor was named after a less stripey southern relative, though it's a bit backwards in that zoologically it's the quagga that's extinct

name: quantum-*
desc: (OpenStack networking service; see also neutron) basically just because it sounds science-y

name: quassel
desc: (IRC client) a German word for "blather" or "jabber"

name: quodlibet
desc: (music organizer) In Latin "quod libet" is "whatever you want"; in English a quodlibet is a particular kind of musical improvization; and in Subversion as it happens the repository started with a "ql" directory (originally "query language"). See also exfalso

name: r10k
desc: (Ruby Puppet deployer) in the style of Randall Munroe's generically-named IRCbot "Robot 9000", but rounded up to 10,000

name: r-base
desc: GNU R is an implementation of S (for Stats) by two people named Ross and Robert

name: radon
desc: (code metrics) probably a reference to the radioactive element formerly used in X-ray machines, and not to the mathematical Radon Transform named after Johann Radon

name: rakudo
desc: (Perl6 implementation) Japanese for Paradise, punning on "rakuda-dō", "the way of the camel"

name: ranger
desc: the name of this vim-like terminal file manager was influenced by other similar file managers like midnight commander and konqueror.  It's a reference to Chuck Norris, the Texas Ranger. The file manager that roundhouse-kicks the others into oblivion!

name: rarian-compat
desc: ex-package; "formerly Spoon" - who knows? the documentation metadata framework is called rarian because it depends on librarian0...

name: rat
desc: (ex-package) VOIP "robust audio tool" produced by the Multimedia Integrated Conferencing for Europe project

name: rawtherapee
desc: that's raw as in "raw digital camera image files" plus a mangled acronym from the experimental raw photo editor

name: rear
desc: disaster recovery tool, short for relax-and-recover

name: recoll
desc: short for "recollect" (i.e. remember where you put things)

name: remmina
desc: GNOME remote desktop client. Unclear, but one backronym that has been offered is "remote mini assistant"

name: remotetea
desc: an esoteric Java ONC/RPC library. Explaining the "remote" part is easy; the reference to tea is trickier (but it's not talking about this kind)

name: rheolef
desc: French, so the "EF" stands for "Éléments Finis" (as in Finite Element Analysis); the "L" may be for "Logiciel" (software) or just part of the word "rhéologie" (fluid mechanics)

name: ries
desc: RILYBOT Inverse Equation Solver

name: ristretto
desc: (image viewer) Italian for a small, concentrated (literally "restricted") shot of espresso coffee. This succeeds in combining the ideas of "powerful" and "lightweight", even if it does misleadingly suggest it's in Java

name: rofi
desc: describes itself as a "window switcher", so presumably it's because "rofi" is "(a) switch" in Icelandic

name: ronn
desc: (man page builder) the current version is technically Ronn-NG, and takes it for granted you know that originally ronn was the opposite of roff

name: root-tail
desc: it doesn't follow the superuser about; it doesn't adhere to the back side of the base mountpoint; it doesn't show the end of an inverse-power frequency distribution; it has nothing to do with rootkits or lemmatization or gardening; it just runs tail and sends its output to the desktop background (the "X root window")

name: rox-filer
desc: (alternative GUI filesystem browser) part of the "ROX" project, which was inspired by the desktop environment on old Acorn computers and stands for "RISC OS on X11"

name: ruby
desc: (programming language) nothing to do with perl, or ruby markup; apparently it was a friend's birthstone (though that sort of explanation would probably work equally well as a justification for calling it Daffodil, Pig, or Cancer)

name: rust
desc: (programming language) named after a fungus that is robust, distributed, and parallel, and its creator is a biology nerd.

name: rxvt-*
desc: Rob Nation's fork of the X11 Virtual Terminal; originally "Robert's" xvt, later "our" xvt

name: sac
desc: for system accounting

name: sahara-*
desc: (OpenStack data processing as a service) formerly savannah, renamed to avoid the usual trademark issues (to a word that may look similar but really has pretty much the opposite connotations)

name: salsa
desc: [not a package] named in a Mexican restaurant

name: samba
desc: the initials of the Server Message Block protocol, plus arbitrary vowels to build a word

name: sanduhr
desc: (ex-package) German for "sand-clock"

name: sapphire
desc: a late-nineties window manager named after a mid-eighties one, the screen allocation package providing helpful icons and rectangular environments

name: sauerbraten
desc: (non-free FPS game engine) from a traditional German style of pot-roast for some reason... it's probably not relevant that the original recipe used pickled horsemeat

name: sawfish
desc: (Lisp window manager) originally sawmill, but changed to avoid a trademark - see (end of) FAQ

name: scala
desc: (programming language) officially either a scalable language or an Italian stairway (rather than a classical scale - see also octave)

name: schleuder
desc: (GPG-enabled mailing list) German for "catapult", which is after all a way of sending things

name: schroot
desc: a replacement for dchroot, which was a "Debian change root" tool (letting you run processes limited to a given directory as if it was the file system root). Originally developed as sbuild-chroot-helper, where the "S" in sbuild stands for source, but the interpretation where it's for "switch" (compare su = "switch user") is also accepted

name: scilab
desc: scientific laboratory - a numerical computation toolkit for processing datasets, compatible with MATLAB ("matrix laboratory")

name: scrobbler
desc: frontend for services like audioscrobbler, a dot-com that existed only just long enough at the turn of the millennium to establish "scrobbling" as a generic word for what it did because these days spying on people's freetime activities counts as a valuable service, even when all the data is held in a wet paper sieve

name: sddm
desc: (KDE5 display manager) the simple desktop display manager, originally developed for OpenBSD's Simple Desktop Environment

name: seafile-*
desc: the name was originally picked for a peer-to-peer network before it became a cloud service

name: semanticscuttle
desc: (ex-package) (PHP bookmark-sharing tool) "semantic" in the "semantic web" sense (i.e. it involves tagging), "scuttle" presumably as a reference to "scuttlebutt" or gossip (or then again maybe it's just a case of scuttled semantics; the package now seems to have been holed below the waterline)

name: senlin
desc: (OpenStack clustering service) from "sēnlín", Mandarin Chinese for "forest"

name: slony1-2-bin
desc: PostgreSQL database-replication server; "slony" ("слоны") is the Russian for elephants, as in the PostgreSQL logo. The numbering is because this package is version 2.x of "Slony-I", not the stalled "Slony-II" branch

name: slrn
desc: slang-based alternative to the traditional USENET client rn ("read news")

name: slurm
desc: (network monitor) a Futurama reference with no obvious justification; unconnected to (and older than) the WorkLoad Manager also known as SLURM (and packaged as slurm-wlm), which has the excuse of being a simple Linux utility for resource management

name: smuxi
desc: smart multiplexed IRC client

name: s-nail
desc: Steffen (Daode) Nurpmeso's revived version of nail (the "new" mail)

name: snort
desc: software for heavy-duty sniffing (probably)

name: sox
desc: long ago short for soundexchange

name: splint
desc: the word "lint" started out as a word for a form of cloth, before becoming US slang for unwanted fluff, and then a verb meaning "remove fluff". In the seventies this verb was turned back into a noun as the name of a utility for "nitpicking" C code. That original utility is long gone, but its name has become a general developerese term for "code debugger", leading to puns like this: splint claims to be "First Aid for programmers" (justifying it as standing for "secure programming lint" or "specifications lint")

name: squid*
desc: (caching web proxy); an arbitrary animal

name: strigi-daemon
desc: (ex-package) (file system indexer) a slightly garbled version of the Latin for "owl" (because owls are well known for... searching through trees and storing what they find? Isn't that squirrels? Oh well, close enough)

name: subtle
desc: subforge.org tiled windowmanager

name: subversion
desc: a version control system that set out to overthrow the established social order (with cvs dominant)

name: sudo
desc: su-do ("perform as superuser"), with a pun on "pseudo" (after all, you're not really logged in as root)

name: sugar-*
desc: (ex-package) (non-desktop-based UI for children) named as something that helps the medicine go down

name: sup-mail
desc: (Ruby MUA) named from the casual greeting "(what')s up?" - not to be confused with the Debian package sup, which is an implementation of the CMU Software Upgrade Protocol system

name: suricata
desc: (network monitor/IDS) the genus Suricata are the meerkats, a relatively non-arbitrary animal

name: swath
desc: smart word analysis for Thai

name: sweep
desc: presumably a sound wave editor something something

name: swift
desc: (OpenStack storage service) a bird that more or less lives in the clouds

name: swig
desc: (C/C++ integration tool for scripting languages) simplified wrapper and interface generator

name: sylpheed
desc: (GTK MUA) the FAQ claims it's because sylphs are lightweight, but that only explains the first syllable

name: sympa
desc: (mailinglist manager) the package description explains that a "système de multi-postage automatique" is an "automatic multi-mailing system", but not that "sympa(thique)" is French for "nice, likeable"

name: sysvinit
desc: the initialization daemon inherited from UNIX System V, which replaced UNIX System IV in 1983 (but the name of its successor systemd does not similarly represent "UNIX System five hundred"). The package contains telinit, which apparently means "tell init" (and confusingly is a symlink to init)

name: tailor
desc: (ex-package) (inter-VCS changeset migrator) obvious once you realise it's dealing with patches

name: tali
desc: formerly gtali short for GNOME Tali, from the Latin for "anklebones", since that's what the Romans used for dice

name: tang
desc: an authentication system named after the projecting "tang" that's part of a lock

name: tar
desc: originally for creating Tape ARchives

name: tcc
desc: a Tiny C Compiler

name: tea
desc: apparently it's a text editor of the atomic era

name: tellico
desc: KDE collection-tracker; just from a placename near where the developer grew up (a controversial dam in Tennessee)

name: telnet
desc: teletype network. Before the days of computer terminals, Teletype was originally a brand of "telegraph typewriters"

name: texlive*
desc: (typesetting system) the "X" in "TeX" is really a Greek "χ" (chi as in "techne" = art/skill/craft); the "live" is because it used to be possible to run upstream versions up to 2009 from a liveCD

name: tgif
desc: antique drawing tool; the name has nothing to do with GIF format (or "thank goodness it's Friday") - it stands for "Tangram Graphic Interface Facility"

name: thuban
desc: (interactive geographic data viewer) Arabic for "snake", but presumably named after Thuban the once-and-future pole star (alpha Draconis)

name: timidity
desc: software synthesizer (i.e. MIDI player), now known upstream as TiMidity++; not related to audacity

name: tmux
desc: multiplexer for virtual consoles. terminal multiplexer.

name: tokyotyrant
desc: network-capable control interface to the tokyocabinet database management library, which is in turn apparently just named after the fact it's Japanese and contains things (likewise the new C++ version, kyotocabinet)

name: tomb
desc: (directory encryption tool) a cobweb-covered pun on "crypt", as in "underground burial vault" not that there's anything secret about a crypt; it's just decently out of sight!

name: tomcat*
desc: Java web server; an arbitrary animal name specifically chosen to get a tomcat onto the O'Reilly book cover

name: trove
desc: (OpenStack DB-as-a-Service) a treasure-trove is a form of longterm storage for valuable stuff, albeit not one that's optimized for convenient access

name: tryton-*
desc: enterprise application framework mainly written in Python. The name is a reference to the programming language and Triton, the largest moon of the planet Neptune, while the logo is a reference to the Triton (or Triturus), a kind of newt (Are we sure it isn't named directly after the Greek god, perhaps incorporating a hint at "three-tier architecture"?)

name: tumbler
desc: Xfce thumbnailer, so named presumably just because it's a cut-down thumbnailer

name: tuskar-*
desc: (ex-package) (OpenStack deployment manager) named (arbitrarily?) after an Irish offshore rock (and lighthouse)

name: *twisted*
desc: (Python network server modules) originated as part of the "Twisted Reality" online interactive fiction system (VR gaming with Python and they didn't call it mudsnake?)

name: twm
desc: officially the "tab window manager" (the idea being that windows with title bars look like folders with tabs), but originally in 1987 "Tom la Strange's WM"

name: typo3
desc: (ex-package) a webCMS named after a dataloss incident

name: u-boot
desc: not built for PC architectures there's clearly a German pun lurking beneath the surface here, but the "U" indicates "Universal" (the same as in GRUB)

name: ucblogo
desc: the version of Logo from the University of California, Berkeley. The name is not an acronym; it's from the Greek for "word" (since it does more than just numbercrunching)

name: udev
desc: as with udisks, ulogd, upower and so on the "U" here stands for "Userspace" - though the "user" in question doesn't necessarily mean the real-life entity between keyboard and chair, just a process not running in kernelspace (i.e. anything from init down to advertising popups)

name: udhcpd
desc: that's not a "U", it's a "μ" (compare udeb or usleep) - this is the micro Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol Daemon

name: ukolovnik
desc: (ex-package) (PHP todo-list) "úkolovnik" is Czech for "task manager"

name: ukui*
desc: desktop for Ubuntu Kylin, a revamp of Kylin OS (named after the "Chinese unicorn")

name: undertaker
desc: (code analysis tool) helps you deal with "dead" (unreachable) codeblocks

name: unixodbc-*
desc: this is the UNIX(-compatible) implementation of the Open DataBase Connectivity interface, not, say, UNIX Objective Design By Contract, or indeed United Nations International X-ray Observatory Dynamic Brake Control

name: unoconv
desc: a format-switcher, but it doesn't extract things from oconv format; it's for converting between the formats used by Open/LibreOffice applications, all of which are built around the Universal Network Objects component model (Just don't ask me what that means or why end-users are supposed to care)

name: uruk
desc: (firewall) named after the strong-walled Mesopotamian city of which Gilgamesh was king likely origin of the name "Iraq"; not after the Black Speech for "orc" in Tolkien

name: uswsusp
desc: originally, userland (but is that "saving the state of the complete desktop session" or "manipulated from userspace"?) software (as in, using ACPI rather than relying on special motherboard features) suspend (meaning both standby-to-RAM and hibernate-to-disk functionality) - but these days different sources interpret the initial letter either as "u"-for-Userspace or as "μ"-for-Micro

name: util-linux
desc: a package with a misleadingly straightforward name. In fact it's essential/required even on Debian GNU/kFreeBSD, and it contains some utilities with outstandingly cryptic names: cytune: [no longer included] for tuning Cyclades-Z multiport serial cards, as used in nineties ISPs dmesg: displays kernel ring buffer messages agetty: "alternative get teletype", which is in fact the standard console login handler mkfs.bfs: a tool for creating SCO UnixWare boot file systems, useful because... EXCUSE NOT FOUND

name: uudeview
desc: named after one of its binaries, a command line uuencode format decoder/viewer dating back to the era of UUCP (Unix to Unix CoPy) connections; the package also contains similar utilities for some less ancient MIME-like encodings

name: valac
desc: compiler for the Vala programming language. There's no official explanation for the name, but the leading theory is that it's a Tolkien reference

name: valentina
desc: a clothes design tool named after famous Ukrainian-emigree fashion designer Valentina Nicholaevna Sanina Schlee

name: valgrind
desc: Code profiler, but not a "value-grinder" (despite the thematic names of its executables). It was originally going to be named Heimdal, but since that was taken they just switched to a different name from Norse myth. Valgrind was the magically protected gateway into Valhalla

name: valinor
desc: ELF debugging tool, and punning Tolkien reference (the Undying Lands that most elves have fled to)

name: vamps
desc: (DVD-ripper) allegedly because it evaporates DVD-compliant MPEG2 program streams

name: vcsh
desc: version control shell or vcs home

name: verdigris
desc: Qt header library inspired by CopperSpice (for C++ aka cpp)

name: vidalia
desc: (ex-package) a GUI for TOR (The Onion Router) named after a kind of onion (state vegetable of Georgia)

name: vile
desc: when it says it's a "VI Like Emacs", it means that it's a vi clone which is relatively similar to emacs, and not the reverse, a "vi-like emacs". Compare zile and the following

name: vim
desc: "vi improved", just as nvi is "new" and elvis is... a word with "vi" in the middle. In all these, "vi" indicates "visual mode" - that is, letting you see the text you're modifying in a full-console display, which had hitherto been an optional extra

name: vinagre
desc: GNOME Remote Desktop/VNC client; named after the Spanish word for vinegar, because vino was taken

name: vlc
desc: VideoLAN project media-player Client

name: w3m
desc: (the text pager that thinks it's a tabbed graphical web browser) "WWW-o miru" is Japanese for "see the World Wide Web"

name: wajig
desc: (omnibus sysadmin wrapper command) sounds like an obvious hybrid of "whatsit", "oojah", and "thingmajig", natural enough for a general-purpose "thingy" command; but the docs insist it's the English word "jig" plus a prefix "wa" (Japanese for "harmony" or "team spirit"). If you say so...

name: wapiti
desc: a web app probing tool, which starts out promisingly but ends up as just another free software ungulate

name: warmux
desc: formerly wormux, which was presumably "Worms clone for Linux", though it's multi-platform and features no actual worms; renamed to avoid confusion and/or litigation. Now canonically capitalized as "WarMUX", though there's no sign of any multiplexing either

name: wayland*
desc: compositing display server to rival X11; named after a town in Massachusetts (not particularly close to Plymouth) that the developer happened to be passing through

name: wcc
desc: the Witchcraft Compiler Collection (performing "binary black magic")

name: weboob
desc: (ex-package) web outside of browsers, with a childish pun on “boobs”

name: weechat
desc: a more-or-less-recursive acronym:  Wee Enhanced Environment for Chat

name: whalebuilder
desc: a tool based on pbuilder but using docker, the logo for which is "Moby Dock", a whale disguised as a container ship

name: whiptail
desc: a dialog system using libnewt and named after a type of lizard (since newts are... almost lizards). "Not Erik's Windowing Toolkit" is a UI library based in turn on S-Lang; and "slang" happens to be Dutch for "snake", though it was intended to indicate that it started as a Stack-based Language.

name: wicd-*
desc: originally the Wireless Interface Connection Daemon, but since it now also handles wired networks it's officially meaningless

name: wine
desc: originally short for WINdows Emulator, but "corrected" to Wine Is Not an Emulator

name: wiredtiger
desc: given that it's a Big Data storage platform, it's more likely to be intended to suggest "cool and fearsomely powerful thing on the network" rather than "as stable as a wildcat on amphetamines"

name: wireshark
desc: this package obviously provides a filigree selachian. Either that or when ethereal got renamed they thought "what way of indicating that it bites up network packets would be coolest and least likely to be trademarked?" Despite the name it also works on wifi networks, and on dry land... (oh, and now there's also "kernelshark", so watch out Tux)

name: wmii
desc: Window Manager Improved Improved, the successor of wmi (Window Manager Improved)

name: wodim
desc: free fork of cdrecord for cdrkit (see also icedax); an approximate acronym for Write Optical DIsk Media, which is intelligible but hardly the first thing you'd guess (Frankly given that it handles Write-Once-Read-Many media I'm astonished it didn't get called "iceworm"...)

name: workrave
desc: RSI preventer; the "work" part makes sense, but what's the "rave"? A dance party? A French turnip?

name: wvdial
desc: upstream were formerly known as "Worldvisions Weaver Software", and parts of this package were known as "weaver", later abbreviated to just "wv-". Nothing to do with the package wv (where it's short for MSWordView)

name: wyrd
desc: (simple calendar app) an unclaimed short word for "that which is destined to happen"

name: x11-*
desc: the eleventh major version of the X Window System (released in 1987; the minor version X11r7 came out in 2005). The X here isn't a type-2; it was originally intended to mark X as a successor to the W Window System developed for the V Operating System

name: *-xapian
desc: a search engine based on code which went through various names with no obvious connection before it went proprietary; this is a free fork with an untrademarked name. It obviously has a type-2 "X" and an "API"; the FAQ admits that there's a vague pun on "sapient" in there too

name: xaw3dg
desc: a library for X-consortium Athena widget-set three-dimensional graphics support, plus a "G" for glibc2 left over from the 1997 libc6 transition (yes, it's another product of Project Athena)

name: xawtv
desc: originally an analog TV viewer based on XAW (as above)

name: xdg-*
desc: some of these packages take the trouble to explain that they come from the FreeDesktop.Org standardization efforts, but not that XDG is short for its previous name, the "X Desktop Group" (a "type-1" X)

name: xemacs*
desc: a fork of GNU Emacs, originally known as Lucid Emacs; when ownership of the Lucid Inc trademark became unclear it was renamed XEmacs, where the X is a "type-2"

name: xen-*
desc: designed for the "Xenoserver Project", where "xeno-" comes from the Greek word "ξένος" meaning "foreigner" or "guest-friend" (that is, a virtualized foreign OS that you allow to run on your server)

name: xfce*
desc: stood for XForms Common Environment while that was accurate, but now doesn't stand for anything (and is thus even harder to distinguish from XKCD)

name: xindy
desc: a LaTeX indexing tool; allegedly stands for "fleXible INDexing sYstem" (which deserves some sort of prize for onomastic obfuscation)

name: xiphos
desc: a Bible-study system based on the SWORD project, and named after a variety of Ancient Greek sword (Is it significant that the xiphos was double-edged?)

name: xli
desc: a longstanding fork of xloadimage (not derived by summing VI + X + X + XV)

name: xmms2
desc: successor to XMMS, which was formerly "X11Amp" (that is, "WinAmp clone for X11"), but officially not a type-1: instead it's "the cross-platform multimedia system"

name: xmount
desc: a forensic tool where the X is neither type-1 nor type-2. Instead it's pronounced "crossmount" (meaning that it translates between disk image formats on the fly)

name: xnee
desc: it may be an X event recorder/replayer, but Xnee's not an event emulator; and roughly the same goes for cnee, gnee, and pnee (in theory their initial letters don't stand for "X11/console/Gnome/gnome-Panel"...)

name: xorriso
desc: a tool for creating .isos (putting an X/Open-compliant file system on a Rock-Ridge-enhanced ISO image), punning incidentally on "sorriso" (Portuguese for "smile") and accidentally on "chorizo" and "xoriço" (Spanish and Catalan for a kind of sausage) (The X/Open part is because it allows more than the POSIX standard. The Rock Ridge Interchange Protocol was so called as a Mel Brooks reference, riffing on the old High Sierra Format - which was named after a hotel.  And finally, the ISO-9660 standard comes from the International Organization for Standardization, which is abbreviated to "ISO" for hazy reasons)

name: xpra
desc: provides X11 persistent remote applications - in other words, it's like a graphical screen for individual application windows on remote systems

name: xulrunner-*
desc: (ex-package) a back-end for things made out of the Mozilla widget-building material known to acronym fans as XUL. That's a Ghostbusters reference as well as a standard piece of Mozilla-speak for "XML UI Language" (where XML is the "eXtensible Markup Language" and a UI is a "User Interface")

name: xxd
desc: the name echoes that of "uudecode" (a conversion tool for an antique ASCII format - see uudeview), though in the case of xxd it's the fact it can encode hexdumps into binaries that sets it apart from the implementations with intelligible names

name: xygrib
desc: a reader to meteorological data in GRIB format (GRIdded Binary or General Regularly-distributed Information in Binary form); forked from zygrib with a similarly arbitrary prefix

name: yabause
desc: yet another buggy and uncomplete Saturn emulator (for the mid-nineties Sega Saturn games console) well, there's one bug already: that should be "INcomplete"

name: yadifa
desc: practically the only thing Wikipedia claims to know is the bit the docs don't mention: it's "yet another DNS implementation for all"

name: yap
desc: yet another Prolog

name: yard
desc: yes, a Ruby documenter; but no, officially it stands for Yay! A Ruby documentation tool

name: yaws
desc: yet another webserver

name: yelp
desc: formerly gnome-help, now inexplicable. Did the word "gelp" get written in hard-to-decipher handwriting, or what?

name: yersinia
desc: (network protocol security tester) named after the bacterium responsible for the black death not a virus, and not a virus-scanner

name: ytalk
desc: Brett Yenne's version of BSD talk

name: zabbix-*
desc: apparently if you take the zabbix.com training course it explains the name

name: zanshin
desc: (KDE notetaking app) Japanese martial-arts term for "relaxed awareness"

name: zapping
desc: a lot of continental Europeans seem to think "zapping" is a cool English word for "channel-hop"

name: zaqar-*
desc: (OpenStack messaging service) formerly named Marconi, but renamed (for the usual trademark reasons) after the Mesopotamian dreamlord Zaqar/Dzakar, messenger of the moongod Sin

name: zathura
desc: the box office flop sequel to Jumanji, which might make trademark-infringing amounts of sense if it was a game, but no, it's a document viewer

name: zemberek-*
desc: (Turkic spellchecker) from the Turkish for "mainspring"; the FAQ used to claim it was because the developer came from a long line of watchmakers, but now it only says it sounds funny. Etymologically it's from the Persian for "bee", so let's just call it an arbitrary animal

name: zenity
desc: (dialog tool) mysterious; presumably the connection with Zen Buddhism is just that it tries to be simple (not connected with the C++ ZenLib)

name: zfs*
desc: the last word in file systems, if only alphabetically; originally the Zettabyte File System

name: zile
desc: zile is lossy emacs - in the figurative sense of "lossy"; literally speaking, it isn't emacs at all, it's zile. Compare vile (but don't bother comparing file or kile)

name: zim
desc: (personal wiki-notepad) unrelated to the ZIM (Zeno IMproved) file format used (e.g.) by the WikiMedia Foundation; the original logo makes it clear it's an Invader Zim reference

name: zlib1g
desc: a compression library. This field has been associated with the letter "Z" since long before PKZip (1989); it may even predate the Lempel-Ziv 1977 algorithm. Back before the days of the LZW-based compress with its .Z extension, /bin/pack used Huffman codes and, for some reason, a .z extension. Oddly, zlib1g isn't the upstream or source package name (that's plain "zlib") or the name of the library it provides (that's "libz1"). The "g" is probably a hangover from the libc6 transition (which means it effectively stands for "glibc2")

name: zomg
desc: (libre.fm client) well, it's implemented in zsh...

name: zope*
desc: (webappserver) "Z Object Publishing Environment" (where the "Z" seems to be just because it's a cool letter)

name: zopfli
desc: a compression tool, with the traditional "Z", named after a Swiss bakery product: "Zopfli" = "little braid". Compare brotli, butteraugli, and guetzli

name: zorp
desc: this appears to be an arbitrary nonsense-syllable, and not (as one might have guessed) the Hungarian for "zonealarm"

name: zotero-*
desc: (ex-package) (bibliographical data-organizer) named from the Albanian verb "zotëro" meaning "to master, acquire"

name: zsh
desc: the Z shell, named because the developer had a colleague named Zhong Shao and thought his login "zsh" looked cool

name: zulucrypt
desc: FS-encryption system so named just because the developer happened to hear the word

name: zypper
desc: (PackageKit software management tool) uses Novell's libZYpp, which has a Z from their "ZEN" ("zero effort networks") and a Y from SuSE's "YaST" ("yet another setup tool")

name: zzuf
desc: a source of "fuzzing", i.e. data corruption for application debugging, which started out with a much ruder name
